Detailed Description

template<class T>
class Vector4< T >

Class for four dimensional vector.

template<class T>
T& Vector4< T >::operator[] ( int  n  )  [inline]

Array access operator.

Parameters:
n Array index
Returns:
For n = 0, reference to x coordinate, n = 1 reference to y coordinate, n = 2 reference to z, else reference to w coordinate. 
01050          {
01051             assert(n >= 0 && n <= 3);
01052             if (0 == n) return x;
01053             else if (1 == n) return y;
01054             else if (2 == n) return z;
01055             else return w;
01056          }

template<class T>
bool Vector4< T >::operator== ( const Vector4< T > &  rhs  )  const [inline]

Equality test operator.

Parameters:
rhs Right hand side argument of binary operator.
Note:
Test of equality is based of threshold EPSILON value. To be two values equal, must satisfy this condition | lws.x - rhs.y | < EPSILON, same for y-coordinate, z-coordinate, and w-coordinate. 
01157          {
01158             return std::fabs(x - rhs.x) < EPSILON 
01159                && std::fabs(y - rhs.y) < EPSILON 
01160                && std::fabs(z - rhs.z) < EPSILON 
01161                && std::fabs(w - rhs.w) < EPSILON;
01162          }

template<class T>
T Vector4< T >::lengthSq (  )  const [inline]

Return square of length.

Returns:
lenght ^ 2
Note:
This method is faster then length(). For comparsion of length of two vector can be used just this value, instead of computionaly more expensive length() method. 
01292          {
01293             return x * x + y * y + z * z + w * w;
01294          }

template<class T>
Vector4<T> Vector4< T >::lerp ( T  fact,
const Vector4< T > &  r 
) const [inline]

Linear interpolation of two vectors.

Parameters:
fact Factor of interpolation. For translation from positon of this vector to vector r, values of factor goes from 0.0 to 1.0.
r Second Vector for interpolation
Note:
Hovewer values of fact parameter are reasonable only in interval [0.0 , 1.0], you can pass also values outside of this interval and you can get result (extrapolation?) 
01307          {
01308             return (*this) + (r - (*this)) * fact;      
01309          }
